Cough: Cough (either new or worsening/exacerbation of chronic cough)
DownloadAppDescription: Read the latest BC Government COVID-19 health guidance and keep your BC vaccine card and Federal COVID-19 Travel Proofs in a single place
Loss of sense of smell or taste: Loss of sense of smell or taste
Q1: Are you experiencing any of the following?
Q1-1: Severe difficulty breathing (e.g. struggling to breathe or speaking in single words)
Q1-3: Having a very hard time waking up
Q2: Are you experiencing any of the following?
Q2-1: Inability to lie down because of difficulty breathing
Q2-2: Chronic health conditions that you are having difficulty managing because of difficulty breathing
Q4: Have you received a new COVID-19 test result?
Q4-desc: If you have not entered it here before, please enter the details of your last COVID-19 test.
Q4-help: Sharing your COVID-19 test results enhances public health's understanding and response to COVID-19.
Q4-Enter the details: Please enter the details of your COVID-19 test:
Question: Question
ResultAsymptomaticNoTest: You do not need a COVID-19 test at this time.
ResultAsymptomaticDescription: If your symptoms change, retake this self-assessment to see if you need testing.
ResultAsymptomaticNotice1: If you have any questions or concerns, contact your health care provider or call <1>8-1-1</1>.
ResultAsymptomaticNotice2: For more information on COVID-19 and how to stay safe, visit the <2>BCCDC website</2>
ResultSymptomaticNoTest: You do not need a COVID-19 test at this time.
ResultSymptomaticNoTestDescription1: Testing is not recommended for adults and children with mild symptoms. Stay home until you feel well enough to resume your regular activities. Avoid high risk settings (e.g. long term care facilities) and individuals at higher risk for severe complications for 10 days after the start of your symptoms.
ResultSymptomaticNoTestDescription2: If you are uncertain and/or feel very sick, call 8-1-1 or contact your primary care provider.
ResultSymptomaticNoTestNotice1: Note that sometimes symptoms may suddenly worsen and require urgent medical care.
ResultSymptomaticNoTestNotice2: Pay attention to how you are feeling. If it becomes harder to breathe, you can’t drink anything or feel much worse, call 9-1-1 or go to your nearest emergency department.
ResultSymptomaticNoTestNotice3: For more information on COVID-19 and how to stay safe, visit the <2>BCCDC website</2>.
ResultSymptomaticTest: Please get a COVID-19 test and self-isolate.
ResultSymptomaticTestDescription1: <0>If you test positive for COVID-19</0>, <2>self-isolate</2> for 10 days from the day your symptoms started.<5 />Public health will contact you within 24-72 hours to follow-up with you.
ResultSymptomaticTestDescription2: <0>If you test negative for COVID-19</0>, stay home until you feel better.
ResultSymptomaticTestDescription3: Get a test at your nearest <1>collection center</1> (mobile and desktop) or click <3>here</3> (for Internet Explorer users).
ResultSymptomaticTestDescription4: <0>Access your test results<0> through any of these services.
ResultSymptomaticTestDescription5: <0>Learn what to do</0> after receiving your test results.
ResultSymptomaticTestDescription6: For more information about the testing options for children and youth, visit <2>COVID-19 Testing for Children and Youth</2>.
ResultSymptomaticTestDescription7: If you are uncertain and/or feel very sick, call 8-1-1 or contact your primary care provider.
ResultSymptomaticTestNotice1: Note that sometimes symptoms may suddenly worsen and require urgent medical care.
ResultSymptomaticTestNotice2: Pay attention to how you are feeling. If it becomes harder to breathe, you can’t drink anything or feel much worse, call 9-1-1 or go to your nearest emergency department.
Result811: Please consult your family doctor or nurse practitioner.
Result811Description: You can call 8-1-1 anytime to talk to a nurse at HealthLinkBC and get advice about how you are feeling and what to do next. Pay attention to how you are feeling. If it becomes harder to breathe, you can’t drink anything or feel much worse, seek urgent medical care at an urgent care clinic or emergency department.
Result811Notice: For more information on where you can call for help, <2>click here</2>.
Result911: Please call 9-1-1 or go directly to your nearest emergency department.
Result911Description: These symptoms require emergency medical care. You should call <1>9-1-1 immediately</1>, or go directly to your nearest emergency department.
Tool description: This online tool will determine whether you may need further assessment or testing for COVID-19.
Home alert: If you have any concerns, feel very sick, or your symptoms are not improving, contact your family doctor/nurse practitioner or call 8-1-1.
HWQ1: Are you an individual who is moderately to severely immunocompromised?
HWQ1-1: You have had an organ transplant and are taking anti-rejection medications
HWQ1-2: You are receiving chemotherapy for cancer
HWQ1-3: You have had a bone marrow or stem cell transplant or CAR-T cell therapy
HWQ1-4: You have been diagnosed with a primary immunodeficiency disorder
HWQ1-5: You have been diagnosed with HIV and are not currently taking medications for it
HWQ1-6: You are on dialysis and/or have severe kidney disease
HWQ2: Are you 18 years of age and older and unvaccinated or partially vaccinated?
HWQ2-description: Unvaccinated or partially vaccinated means you have not received at least 2 doses of a 2-dose series or more than 14 days after receiving a single dose of a 1-dose series.
HWQ3: Do you work as a health care worker in a hospital, long-term care facility, assisted living facility, or community clinic, or as a first responder (i.e. police officer, emergency medical technician/paramedic, or firefighter)?
HWQ4: Do you live or work in a congregate setting (such as a long term care facility, shelter, correctional facility, or group home) or in a community that is far from testing centres and hospitals (such as rural, remote, isolated, or Indigenous community or a work camp)?
